prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Ophiuchus Class I sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is the science goal to observe the Ophiuchus Class I sample in lines of C17O, C34S, H13CO+, ...

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The aim of this science goal is to image line emission toward each of the 12 objects from a sample of Class I protostars from the Ophiuchus molecular cloud at 0.5" resolution. We have chosen a spectral setup covering C17O 3-2, C34S 7-6 at 337.0-337.3 GHz GHz, H13CO+ 4-3 at 347 GHz the main part of the CH3OH 7-6 branch around 338.4 GHz and finally CH3CN and C2H around 349.3 GHz.
The sensitivity limit is driven by the desire to detect the CH3OH branch - the lines of the more common species C17O, C34S and H13CO+ being brighter, or at least, comparable to this in our Cycle 0 data. The line strengths are estimated adopting a model for the envelope around each source based on dust radative transfer modeling of their submillimeter continuum emission and SEDs - adopting a conservative CH3OH abundance of 1e-9 in the inner region where the temperature is above 100 K (Table 1). We aim for a signal-to-noise of at least 5 for each source - leading to a sensitivity requirement of 5 mJy / km/s for each source.

The basebands are configured to provide high spectral resolution (0.12 km/s) on the lines of C17O, C34S and H13CO+ probing the dynamics on the scales of the embedded circumstellar disk - and a factor two coarser resolution in the other two basebands in order to include a larger bandwidth, e.g., cover more of the CH3OH transitions.

We adopt an angular resolution of 0.5" sufficient to resolve the inner envelopes and disks around Class I protostars at the distance of Ophiuchus - as well as reveal the presence of extended regions where, e.g., water or methanol could be coming off dust grains in accretion bursts.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA is already providing exciting results on how circumstellar disks form around low-mass young stars and how they evolve from the embedded through planet-forming stages. In this program we will attack the question: What is the relation between the formation and early evolution of circumstellar disks and the physics of the inner regions of collapsing protostellar envelopes? This proposal is a resubmission of a B-ranked Cycle 2 program for which no data have been taken so-far. We will utilize ALMA's Band-7 to image a representative sample of 12 embedded protostars from the Ophiuchus star forming region in molecular lines from a selected set of isotopologues of common molecular species probing material with high temperatures and densities in the inner envelopes and circumstellar disks. This study will begin the process of assembling the key statistics required to understand the formation and early evolution of circumstellar disks, as well as provide key insight into the physics and timing of protostellar accretion.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Resubmission of B-ranked Cycle 2 proposal: 2013.1.00955.S, "Properties and Evolution of Embedded Protostellar Disks", PI: Jes Jorgensen
